docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has issued a preliminary injunction barring penalties against a business whose health coverage for employees does not cover contraception or abortion pills.

headline.main: Colorado: Judge Bars Penalties Against Employer, for Now
headline.print_headline: Colorado: Judge Bars Penalties Against Employer, for Now

docs.abstract: Federal Judge John Kane issues a preliminary injunction barring penalties against Hercules Industries, a heating and air-conditioning business whose health coverage for employees does not cover contraception or abortion pills; the health care reform legislation requires group health plans to offer women no-cost preventive care coverage for items including contraception.
docs.snippet: A federal judge has issued a preliminary injunction barring penalties against a business whose health coverage for employees does not cover contraception or abortion pills.

docs.snippet: Pfizer describes its programs to provide drugs to those who cannot afford them.

docs.lead_paragraph: Palermo’s Pizza fired scores of employees at its Milwaukee factory, citing immigration violations, shortly after workers said they wanted to organize.

headline.seo: Striking Palermo’s Pizza Workers Say Immigrants Were Fired to Stop a Union

docs.abstract: Labor organizers have criticized Palermo Villa Inc for asking 89 immigrant workers to verify their right to work in the United States, calling it a naked attempt to prevent its workforce from unionizing; conflict highlights how difficult it can be to organize workplaces that include unauthorized workers, who are entitled to certain labor protections despite working illegally.
docs.snippet: Palermo’s Pizza fired scores of employees at its Milwaukee factory, citing immigration violations, shortly after workers said they wanted to organize.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and STEVEN YACCINO

docs.lead_paragraph: If your company’s pension plan offers a lump sum payout or a monthly check from an annuity, which makes more sense? The answer may be in the mirror.

headline.seo: Retirees’ Choice of Payout vs. Monthly Check - Wealth Matters
headline.main: When Your Pension Offers a Choice
headline.print_headline: When Your Pension Offers a Choice

docs.abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column provides advice on whether it is better for retirees to accept a lump sum payment at retirement, or continue to receive an annuity; contends that the decision is a complex one, in which health, family and the long-term viability of the company are in play.
docs.snippet: If your company’s pension plan offers a lump sum payout or a monthly check from an annuity, which makes more sense? The answer may be in the mirror.

headline.main: A New Ad Campaign for Kaiser Permanente

docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente, one of the largest health care providers in the United States, is rolling out the latest installment of its advertising campaign, "Thrive," on Friday.

docs.abstract: Taiwan not only has in place a national health care system, but it also takes advantage of information technology far more frequently than the United States does.

docs.abstract: Dr. Timothy Lepore, the only surgeon working on Nantucket island, has taken it upon himself to deliver whatever type of medical care his island inhabitants need, often challenging conventional notions of medicine and redefining what it means to be a healer.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s health care law is putting new strains on some hard-pressed facilities, by cutting aid they use to pay for emergency care for illegal immigrants.

headline.seo: Affordable Care Act Reduces Fund for Uninsured, Worrying Hospitals
headline.main: Hospitals Fear Cuts in Aid for Care to Illegal Immigrants
headline.print_headline: Hospitals Worry Over Cut In Fund For Uninsured

docs.abstract: Health care reform law is putting new strains on some of the nation's most hard-pressed hospitals by cutting aid they use to pay for emergency care for illegal immigrants, which they have long been required to provide; law will eventually cut the money used to reimburse hospitals for treating more than their share of the uninsured, and so-called safety net hospitals say cuts will deal a severe blow to their finances.
docs.snippet: President Obama’s health care law is putting new strains on some hard-pressed facilities, by cutting aid they use to pay for emergency care for illegal immigrants.

docs.lead_paragraph: Going against a decade of rulings, a federal appeals court said payments aimed at holding back generics were anticompetitive, setting up possible review by the Supreme Court.

headline.main: For Big Drug Companies, a Headache Looms
headline.print_headline: For Big Drug Companies, a Headache Looms

docs.abstract: Ruling by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia found that pharmaceutical companies who pay generic drug makers to keep their products off the market are engaging in anticompetitive behavior; ruling bucks several federal decisions over the last decade and gives the Supreme Court a strong reason to address the issue.
docs.snippet: Going against a decade of rulings, a federal appeals court said payments aimed at holding back generics were anticompetitive, setting up possible review by the Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consolidated Edison and its largest union announced a tentative agreement on a contract on Thursday, several hours after Gov.Andrew M. Cuomo intervened personally in their monthlong labor dispute. About 8,000 of the utility's workers had been locked out since July 1. Since then, about 5,000 Con Ed managers and retired workers kept the company's electrical system operating amid hot weather and high demand for air-conditioning.

headline.main: Tentative Deal in Con Ed Labor Dispute

docs.abstract: Consolidated Edison and its largest union announce a tentative contract agreement; move comes within hours of intervention from New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo in the month-long labor lock-out that left 5,000 Con Ed managers and retired workers keeping the company's electrical systems in New York City operating amid hot weather and high demand for air-conditioning. Photo (M)
